awd_titl_txt: Examining Shifting Geographies of Historically Underrepresented Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the shifting geographies of an historically marginalized population. Such a population, though historically invisible, has had a profound impact on shaping local landscapes. The investigators will develop a set of novel methods to create a large-scale, publicly accessible and interactive database of locations pertinent to a diverse, underrepresented community over time. Using a variety of quantitative, qualitative, and technical methods, the investigators then plan to analyze the database to evaluate hypotheses about where, how, and why historically invisible communities grow and change. The project’s results will improve the understanding of these processes while also demonstrating the utility of its innovative methods, while the creation of a new publicly accessible Historical Geographic Information System (HGIS) database is a future resource for the community. In addition, the project will train and mentor graduate and undergraduate students in STEM methods and facilitate bridge-building between different theoretical and methodological traditions in the social sciences. Finally, the project will broaden opportunities for participation by the general public in social science research and serve as a model for how HGIS can be used to improve understanding of diverse communities’ invisible histories and shifting geographies. 

The project is relevant because little is known or understood about where, how, and why historically underrepresented communities grow and change, or about how to study these processes across broader scales in a scientific way. Often, most of what is known about such populations is based on a small number of localized historical case studies, which limit their potential for generalizability and the generation of new knowledge.  This project is a comparative study over time as it collects data about the locations and key characteristics of an historically underrepresented group in a large national sample.  Methods include the integration of an extensive variety of archival sources and an interactive online geospatial platform.  Results will be analyzed systematically, using a variety of quantitative, qualitative, and technical methods, to test key hypotheses from urban and cultural geography, such as gentrification. The results will improve understanding not only of where and how historically underrepresented communities grow and change but will also lead to the development of innovative methods about how such changes might be studied.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project created an expandable dataset consisting of annual entries for venues in 13 cities of various sizes across multiple regions of the U.S. between 1965-2014 from archived copies of Damron Travel Guides. The project also created a geospatial platform where the data is hosted (https://hgis.uw.edu/lgbtqspaces/). The platform allows users to visualize changes in the spatial patterns of these venues over time, at various scales, to contribute new data, and to download the dataset for their own uses (e.g., academic, civic engagement, preservationist).  See the attached images for examples of how the platform can be used to visualize changes in these patterns.

With respect to the dataset, the project developed a data structure framework that can manage both the initial Damron Travel Guide data and users’ contributions. With respect to the platform, it features a public-facing web portal that visualizes the venues and observations in space and time using an innovative 3D web mapping approach.  A graphic user interface (GUI) mock-up served as a visual counterpart that assisted in development of the geospatial platform’s design and development.

The overall system architecture enables anonymous users to browse the venues on maps or tables and to contribute their own data.  It also allows researchers to improve the accuracy of the locational data.  A pilot study of the system’s functionality using a subset of the data and volunteer users was a crucial step in testing and improving the performance of the platform.  A workshop designed to educate users in how to access, navigate, and contribute to the geospatial platform and interact with it was also developed and tested.

Over the life of the project numerous graduate and undergraduate students learned how to organize and process raw data, design geospatial data structures, and develop a system architecture for a geospatial platform.  Undergraduates have gone on to highly-ranked geography or data science graduate programs at Duke University, University of Wisconsin, and University of Washington while others gained employment at local geospatial technology companies.  Graduate students, meanwhile, gained valuable experience in mentoring, team leadership, and some aspects of project administration.

Finally, in addition to the database, the project resulted in three refereed journal articles (two in Annals of the American Association of Geographers and one in Urban Studies) and one major conference presentation.


Last Modified: 12/10/2024
Modified by: Lawrence M Knopp
